reviews.review_msg: 2 group projects and 1 midterm worth 30% of your grade. The midterm was based on a HBR article and you had a week to complete it. She was pretty helpful with questions from students and her class was 100% online!!

Readings every week which were part of the weekly discussion. Only one exam & we had a week to complete it. Participation is important, so you need to show up to every class. I really enjoyed her class, its a easy A if you put in the effort. I highly recommend taking Lily as she explains the material well, and is very approachable.

Lily was a great professor for an online class! She used both asynchronous and synchronous teaching methods. Synchronous classes were mainly used for discussion going over the main concepts from the asynchronous lectures. Overall a really interesting class and very well organized.

Honestly don't know whether she realizes how unclear and unspecific with most if not all the assignments and tasks. Instead of providing clear expectations of the assignments and indicating deadlines on the syllabus, she makes them up as she goes. Highly disappointed in this course and in her teaching ability and wished I took it with another prof.

Lisa is as passionate as it comes, thought it is solely based on sustainability, the course has been applicable in real-life situations. This is by far the most "entertaining" course I have taken at SFU as it isn't just dry textbook reading, instead it is applying yourself and your skills. This being said, the group projects are a lot of work
Good prof, enjoyed having her. Cares about the students on aspects outside of pure academics.

She is a very passionate and caring Professor. She proactively works to develop environmentally positive and sustainable attitudes in students in the business faculty, a faculty that often gets a bad rep for being focused on profit. I recommend her course, but you will have to work hard to be rewarded with a top grade.
She is the best SFU teacher I've ever met in my life. She is so nice that she cancled the 2500 words paper at the end of the sem because we said we were too tired.~~~

Class is a bit misleading (this is new product development, not new venture marketing) - but whole entrep. program needs to be revised. Prof is excellent, with some great experience. Very enthusiastic and helpful. Highly recommended so long as you work hard!

Emily is one of the most passionate and kind professors I have had during my time at SFU. Her classes aren't necessarily easy and you need to work hard if you want to achieve a good grade, but she's always willing to help out when needed.
Emphasize heavily on quick communication outside of classroom. Very engaging lectures and minimal work. The two negative reviews don't do her justice at all.

Worst professor I have had at SFU. Just awful, lack of experience, passive aggressiveness & the inability to be impartial. We had to purchase weekly readings outside of tuition, and participation marks were awarded based on irrelevant comments. Thick accent, spelling & grammar errors in her slides. It was a frustrating and disappointing semester.

Unclear requirements for all assignments, and grades participation as if it were a final exam during every lecture. Expect to participate nonstop during class because you will receive 1/4 if you only answer "easy" questions in her eyes. The language barrier means she will misunderstand you, and dock you points for her own shortcomings. Ridiculous.
